prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Spectral and Correlator Configuration: Two basebands are positioned to align at their edges in the LSB to cover the line, which is centered between them to maximize velocity coverage in the hope of seeing other sources in the field. These basebands are both in FDM mode, with spectral averaging set to 16, which is still adequate resolution for this source. Flexibility in matching channels across lines is preserved by not allowing the resolution to be too coarse (e.g., the 40 km/s of the TDM mode). The other sideband has two TDM basebands for continuum sensitivity.
Imaging Requirements: For all sources we simulated the lensing of a population of source clumps in the approximate region of the source plane occupied by the continuum source identified in the ALMA cycle 0 measurements. The clump parameters (velocity structure, size, position) were varied to consider a range of filling factors and a reference configuration was adopted that had velocity structure similar to the observed CII line and provided a somewhat pessimistic forecast for the peak line signal compared to some more compact models. For the goal of high source-plane resolution, the maximum possible imaging resolution is desirable. However, at finer resolution the flux is split among a greater number of beams and the significance of the image peaks decreases. The balance struck between resolution and sensitivity across all lines in the calculation described below was 0.25" (except for the very bright CII). This is close to the maximum resolution for the NII 205 line.
Sensitivity Requirements: The source model described above had its channel fluxes normalized to match a calculated line flux for each transition. For NII205, the line flux was taken to be 6% of the observed CII flux of 75 Jy km/s. The 6% was chosen to be more conservative than was recently observed in a z=4.76 galaxy by ALMA (DeBreuck, priv. comm.). The sensitivity target of the observation was adjusted to deliver a peak SNR of 15 per beam in a 100 km/s channel. This provides a significant margin for the uncertainties inherent in the fluxes of these fine structure lines. As noted in the proposal, for the purposes of source plane reconstruction, the flux is added across pixels in a highly constrained way, due to the known lens geometry, meaning that the actual signal to noise in the source plane will be considerably higher.

Spectral and Correlator Configuration: Two basebands are positioned to align at their edges in the LSB to cover the line, which is centered between them to maximize velocity coverage in the hope of seeing other sources in the field. These basebands are both in FDM mode, with spectral averaging set to 16, which is still adequate resolution (8 km/s) for this source. Because of the high signal to noise in CII, 30km/s resolution in FDM mode is undesirable. The other sideband has two TDM basebands for continuum sensitivity.
Imaging Requirements: For all sources we simulated the lensing of a population of source clumps in the approximate region of the source plane occupied by the continuum source identified in the ALMA cycle 0 measurements. The clump parameters (velocity structure, size, position) were varied to consider a range of filling factors and a reference configuration was adopted that had velocity structure similar to the observed CII line and provided a somewhat pessimistic forecast for the peak line signal compared to some more compact models. For the goal of high source-plane resolution, the maximum possible imaging resolution is desirable, and for the bright CII line, the max resolution of 0.15" was selected.
Sensitivity Requirements: The source model described above had its channel fluxes normalized to match the observed CII flux of 75 Jy km/s. The sensitivity target of the observation was adjusted to deliver a peak SNR of 15 per beam in a 25 km/s channel. This requires just a few minutes on source for this bright line. That we can achieve such high signal to noise at 4x higher resolution than the other lines will aid in the spectral lens modeling for this source.

Spectral and Correlator Configuration: The NII 122 line is near to an oxygen absorption line, which falls below the frequency of interest. An FDM baseband with 16x spectral averaging is centered on this line, and a TDM baseband is abutted above it. The 1500 km/s width of the FDM band is sufficient to cover the line on its own. The other sideband has two TDM basebands for continuum sensitivity.
Imaging Requirements: For all sources we simulated the lensing of a population of source clumps in the approximate region of the source plane occupied by the continuum source identified in the ALMA cycle 0 measurements. The clump parameters (velocity structure, size, position) were varied to consider a range of filling factors and a reference configuration was adopted that had velocity structure similar to the observed CII line and provided a somewhat pessimistic forecast for the peak line signal compared to some more compact models. For the goal of high source-plane resolution, the maximum possible imaging resolution is desirable. However, at finer resolution the flux is split among a greater number of beams and the significance of the image peaks decreases. The balance struck between resolution and sensitivity across all lines in the calculation described below was 0.25" (except for the very bright CII).
Sensitivity Requirements: The source model described above had its channel fluxes normalized to match a calculated line flux for each transition. For NII122, this is taken from the Spinoglio et al 2012 relations between L_FIR and line fluxes from ISO data. The sensitivity target of the observation was adjusted to deliver a peak SNR of 15 per beam in a 100 km/s channel. This provides a significant margin for the uncertainties inherent in the fluxes of these fine structure lines. As noted in the proposal, for the purposes of source plane reconstruction, the flux is added across pixels in a highly constrained way, due to the known lens geometry, meaning that the actual signal to noise in the source plane will be considerably higher. Because of the atmospheric absorption on the red side of the line, we aim for noise 30% lower than calculated by our normal method to ensure that the signal to noise is not very compromised on the red side.

Spectral and Correlator Configuration: The OI 63 um line is in band 9, and so the basebands are only 800 km/s wide. Two are used to straddle the line, both in TDM mode because its resolution corresponds to 13 km/s. Two more TDM basebands are added at lower frequency, spanning most of the IF in this DSB receiver.
Imaging Requirements: For all sources we simulated the lensing of a population of source clumps in the approximate region of the source plane occupied by the continuum source identified in the ALMA cycle 0 measurements. The clump parameters (velocity structure, size, position) were varied to consider a range of filling factors and a reference configuration was adopted that had velocity structure similar to the observed CII line and provided a somewhat pessimistic forecast for the peak line signal compared to some more compact models. For the goal of high source-plane resolution, the maximum possible imaging resolution is desirable. However, at finer resolution the flux is split among a greater number of beams and the significance of the image peaks decreases. The balance struck between resolution and sensitivity across all lines in the calculation described below was 0.25" (except for the very bright CII).
Sensitivity Requirements: The source model described above had its channel fluxes normalized to match a calculated line flux for each transition. For OI63, this is taken from the Spinoglio et al 2012 relations between L_FIR and line fluxes from ISO data. The sensitivity target of the observation was adjusted to deliver a peak SNR of 8 per beam in a 100 km/s channel for this line because of the difficulty of conducting Band 9 observations. This source is likely to be overluminous in OI, so this is probably a conservative estimate. As noted in the proposal, for the purposes of source plane reconstruction, the flux is added across pixels in a highly constrained way, due to the known lens geometry, meaning that the actual signal to noise in the source plane will be considerably higher. An oxygen absorption line (715 GHz) will cause some loss of sensitivity on the blue side of the line. The most absorbed baseband was therefore used as the reference frequency, corresponding to a point 400 km/s to the blue of the line center.

Spectral and Correlator Configuration: The OI 146 line lies less than 1.875 GHz from the CO18-17 line. To include both in the correlator setup, an FDM band was centered on the CO line and a second one was abutted on the low frequency side to capture OI. This maximizes the velocity coverage around OI. Both are set to 16x averaging. The other sideband has two TDM basebands for continuum sensitivity.
Imaging Requirements: For all sources we simulated the lensing of a population of source clumps in the approximate region of the source plane occupied by the continuum source identified in the ALMA cycle 0 measurements. The clump parameters (velocity structure, size, position) were varied to consider a range of filling factors and a reference configuration was adopted that had velocity structure similar to the observed CII line and provided a somewhat pessimistic forecast for the peak line signal compared to some more compact models. For the goal of high source-plane resolution, the maximum possible imaging resolution is desirable. However, at finer resolution the flux is split among a greater number of beams and the significance of the image peaks decreases. The balance struck between resolution and sensitivity across all lines in the calculation described below was 0.25" (except for the very bright CII).
Sensitivity Requirements: The source model described above had its channel fluxes normalized to match a calculated line flux for each transition. For OI146, this is taken from the Spinoglio et al 2012 relations between L_FIR and line fluxes from ISO data. The sensitivity target of the observation was adjusted to deliver a peak SNR of 15 per beam in a 100 km/s channel. This provides a significant margin for the uncertainties inherent in the fluxes of these fine structure lines. As noted in the proposal, for the purposes of source plane reconstruction, the flux is added across pixels in a highly constrained way, due to the known lens geometry, meaning that the actual signal to noise in the source plane will be considerably higher. Because of the atmospheric absorption on the red side of the line, we aim for noise 30% lower than calculated by our normal method to ensure that the signal to noise is not very compromised on the red side.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to observe a full diagnostic suite of five far-IR fine structure lines in an extraordinary starburst galaxy at the end of cosmic reionization. Through the power of gravitational lensing, our observations will measure the metallicity, radiation field, density, kinematics, and AGN effects with effective resolution of a few hundred parsecs, which has only been possible to date in the nearest star-forming galaxies. SPT0346-52, at z=5.7, already has high-resolution maps of the dust continuum and low-J CO emission, as well as integrated measurements of mid-J CO, [CII], and full radio-to-IR SED coverage. These observations effectively complement Herschel studies of local ULIRGs, and extend the study of these lines to the first Gyr of cosmic history. The high sensitivity, high resolution studies made possible by ALMA will address several key questions about the first stages of galaxy evolution, including the production of heavy elements, stellar and AGN feedback mechanisms, the energetics of the ISM, and the dynamics of the first galaxies.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
